Code chunks
R code chunks are placeholders for the coding part of the document, expressed with a local header, and a body part.

Headers

Headers optionsOptions hierarchy



code chunk

Options are used to show/hide the code, change the size of the output image, set the alignment of the ouptut, etc.

code chunk
{r setup, include=FALSE}
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)

The top chunk of the .Rmd file is commonly used to set global options for all subsequent chunks, unless you override these options locally within the headers of individual code chunks.

title: Authoring, writing and publishing withR Markdown - part 2
text:
Code evaluation

code chunk
{r munsingenspat, echo = TRUE, warning = FALSE, message = FALSE}







code


description






include = FALSE


prevents code and results from appearing in the rendered file. R Markdown still runs the code in the chunk, and the results can be used by other chunks.




echo = FALSE


prevents code, but not the results from appearing in the rendered file.




message = FALSE


prevents messages that are generated by code from appearing in the rendered file.




warning = FALSE


prevents warnings that are generated by code from appearing in the rendered file.

Graphical options

code chunk
{r munsingenspat, fig.height = 10, fig.with = 10}







code


description






fig.cap = "..."


adds a caption to graphical results.




fig.height = 7


height for plots created by the chunk (in inches).




fig.width = 7


width for plots created by the chunk (in inches).




fig.align = default


how to align graphics in the final document. One of 'left', 'right', or 'center'.




fig.pos = 'H'


fix the output exactly here.

title: Authoring, writing and publishing withR Markdown - part 2
text:
Body
The body of a code chunk is where you place the R code

code chunk
{r munsingenspat, echo=TRUE, warning = FALSE, message = FALSE}
library(dplyr)
library(leaflet)
munsingen.long <- 7.569587484129203
munsingen.lat <- 46.864709895956004
leaflet(width = "60%", height = "400px") %>%
  addTiles(group = 'OSM') %>%
  addControl("Munsingen necropolis", position = "bottomright") %>%
  addProviderTiles(providers$Esri.WorldImagery, group='Esri.WorldImagery') %>%
  addMarkers(munsingen.long,
             munsingen.lat,
             label = "Munsingen necropolis") %>%
  addLayersControl(
    baseGroups = c('OSM', 'Esri.WorldImagery')) %>%
  addScaleBar(position = "bottomleft")

Interactivity

ShinyLeafletPlotly


Shiny offers a framework to create interactive documents

header YAML
runtime: shiny







Note


Try: File > New File > Rmarkdown > Shiny, or in the YAML header. There are different ways to use Shiny in R Markdown, for example by embedding an HTML widget created by Shiny outside the R Markdown document, or by embedding the Shiny coding directly.







Maps with the  package 

code chunk

library(dplyr)
library(leaflet)
munsingen.long <- 7.569587484129203
munsingen.lat <- 46.864709895956004
leaflet(width = "90%", height = "300px") %>%
  addTiles(group = 'OSM') %>%
  addControl("Munsingen necropolis", position = "bottomright") %>%
  addProviderTiles(providers$Esri.WorldImagery, group='Esri.WorldImagery') %>%
  addMarkers(munsingen.long,
             munsingen.lat,
             label = "Munsingen necropolis") %>%
  addLayersControl(
    baseGroups = c('OSM', 'Esri.WorldImagery')) %>%
  addScaleBar(position = "bottomleft")










2D plots with the  package 

code chunk

library(plotly)
library(dplyr)
library(archdata)
data("Fibulae")
Fibulae.ex <- Fibulae
Fibulae.ex$lbl <- paste0("<b>Museum num.: ", Fibulae.ex$Mno, "</b><br>",
                          "Length: ", Fibulae.ex$Length, "<br>",
                          "Foot Angle: ", Fibulae.ex$FA, "<br>")
plot_ly(data = Fibulae.ex, 
        x = ~Length,
        y = ~FA,
        text = ~lbl,
        hoverinfo = "text")

Note


For advanced editing, read below



 is useful in R Markdown for chunk calls, and more generally for cross-referencing. PDF uses LaTeX syntax, if you donâ€™t have MiKTeX installed, you need to install the  package (Xie 2019).

install.packages('tinytex')
tinytex::install_tinytex()
# .rs.restartR()

To export in PDF, use bookdown::pdf_document2: and knit.

header YAML
---
title: "temp"
output: pdf_document
date: '2023-02-05'
output:
  bookdown::pdf_document2:
    css: styles.css
    toc: yes
    toc_depth: 4
    toc_float:
      collapsed: no
bibliography: references.bib
---

title: Authoring, writing and publishing withR Markdown - part 2
text:
LaTeX
LaTeX (extension of TeX) is a rich plain text syntax for academic writing. To export in TeX, select in the YAML header a PDF export + keep tex:

header YAML
---
title: "temp"
date: '2023-02-05'
output:
  bookdown::pdf_document2: 
    keep_tex: true
---
